Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Studies of a Weakly Collisional Plasma: Landau Damping and 3D BGK Modes
Award.AbstractNarration:
High temperature plasmas, such as those in fusion devices and in many astrophysical cases, are characterized by extremely low collision frequencies. Classical collisionless theoretical treatments have produced interesting and fundamentally important results, such as Landau damping in the linear regime, and Bernstein-Greene-Kruskal (BGK) modes in one dimension (1D) for the nonlinear case. However, a real plasma actually has a certain level of collisions, no matter how weak it is. Recently the physical picture of Landau damping with weak collisions has been shown to be completely different from the collisionless case [Ng, Bhattacharjee and Skiff,Phys. Rev. Lett. 92, 065002 (2004); 83, 1974 (1999)]. This occurs because the collision term
actually represents a singular perturbation of the collisionless problem, and will become important when sharp gradients develop in the velocity space. Such sharp gradients also invalidate assumptions of linearization so that nonlinear effects must be included. At the same time, higher dimensional effects, which are important to explain observations, also completely change the properties of BGK modes [Ng and Bhattacharjee, Phys. Rev. Lett., 95, 245004 (2005); Ng, Bhattacharjee and Skiff, Phys. Plasmas, 13, 055903 (2006)].

In this project, the nonlinear dynamics of Landau damping and 2D/3D BGK modes in a weakly collisional plasma will be studied, by means of analysis as well as direct Boltzmann simulations with a Fokker-Planck type collision term. These studies will be carried out with increasing levels of realism and sophistication: starting with 1D Boltzmann simulations for the Landau damping problem, and following up with 1D spatial and 2D velocity space simulations for the symmetric higher dimensional BGK modes. Results of the studies will be compared with laboratory and space observations. This is a subject of broad interest because, as is well known, the underlying physics of Vlasov equation/Landau damping/BGK modes not only applies in high temperature plasmas, as in laboratory experiments and space/astrophysical environments, but also exists in similar form in many different physical systems, e.g., beams in particle accelerators, galactic dynamics, ocean waves, Bose-Einstein condensates, trapped electron devices. The codes developed in this project will be available for the scientific community for other research. This project also involves significant interactions between theory and experiments, such as those performed by Prof. F. Skiff at the University of Iowa as well as numerous observations of solitary wave-type structures in space. This project will support a graduate student, and partially for a postdoctoral research fellow, who will also receive mentoring activities. Results from this project will be published in scientific journals, and summarized in a website.

This project will also allow supported researchers to participate in education and outreach activities around the University of Alaska Fairbanks area, such as those organized through the Public Information and Education Outreach Office of the Geophysical Institute, or those coordinated by the UAF Science education Outreach Network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies some fundamental dynamics of how high-temperature plasma (a state of matter in which electrons have escaped out of atoms leaving behind positive ions) with electro-magnetic fields. One property of such high-temperature state of matter is that collisions among electrons and ions are getting much less frequent so that interaction within such ionized gas is dominated by long-range electro-magnetic force, rather than forces due to particles colliding with each other. The electro-magnetic waves propagating within such system can exhibit very unusual properties. For example, energy can go from waves to particles so that the wave is damped in the process called Landau damping. On the other hand, energy can also be transferred from particles back to waves. When the wave has larger amplitude so that the interaction between waves and particles is no longer proportional to the wave amplitude, in the so-called non-linear regime, energy can go in both directions or even in such a way that semi-stable structures combining both electro-magnetic fields and charged particles can form. Some of such structures can be described in theory as so-called BGK modes. In such cases, the properties of the plasma are fundamentally changed. Therefore, it is very important to study how waves interact with particles in various situations, and how self-organized structures form and exist in plasma.

     The physics studied in this project is not only highly interesting academically, but is also very important in the defense against harmful effects due to strong space storms. This is because the earth is surrounded by plasma trapped by the magnetic field of the earth. This is called the magnetosphere. At the same time, a constant flow of high-speed plasma is coming from the sun to the earth all the time, i.e., the solar wind, and makes impact on the magnetosphere. Occasionally the impact by the solar wind becomes much stronger due to storms on the surface of the sun (solar flares). Such strong impact can then drive the magnetosphere to develop strong magnetic storms that can cause highly damaging effects on spacecraft, satellites, or the power grids. Such events are characterized as space weather. However, due to complex dynamics of plasma, our ability to study and forecast space weather is still very limited, despite much progress made over the last couple of decades. Part of the difficulty in doing so is due to the non-linear interaction between particles and electro-magnetic fields. In particular, the existence of small-scale dynamical structures can have great implication on how fast space storms can develop and thus how strong and damaging they can be. Therefore, the study conducted by this project is important to the understanding of space weather and the development of forecasting capabilities.

     Research for this project has resulted in new theories and numerical solutions for the interaction between waves and particles, as well as small-scale non-linear structures described as higher-dimensional BGK modes. By the support from this project, four refereed papers have been published. Another four papers are in preparation and will be submitted for publication soon. Also research results have been presented in 17 scientific meetings to share with other scientists. This project has supported a graduate student throughout his master study until he obtained his master degree. Three postdoctoral researchers have also worked for this project with one of them receiving support for more than two years. The Principle Investigator of this project has also incorporated some of the research experience from this project into his teaching of graduate courses, as well as internal talks given at the University of Alaska Fairbanks.
